title: Proposed OpenMaterial_material_parameters glTF extension
description: Material properties needed to render physically realistic materials

user_preferences.description: Material properties that could change when material is applied to geometry

geometrical_optics.description: If it is true, geometrical optics will be used which is valid when the size of the geometry structure of the object is much larger than the incident wavelength.

include_diffraction.description: If it is true, diffraction models will be included in the interactions. Examples of methods are Unified Theory of Diffraction (UTD) - Geometrical Theory of Diffraction (GTD).

include_numerical_simulation.description: If it is true, numerical methods will compute the electromagnetic field. Examples of methods are BEM (Boundary Elements Method), FEM (Finite Element Method), FDTD (Finite Difference Time Domain), and FMM (Fast Multiple Method).

material_scheme.description: Material scheme can be surface, subsurface or volume.

material_classification.description: It provides information about the hierarchical classification of the material. The first hierarchy level is either solid, liquid or gas. The lower hierarchy levels can be chosen by the user. The hierarchy levels are separated by ‘–‘ sign. The classification can be used for searching and filtering similar to tags. As an example, a classification of aluminium can be “solid-metal-aluminium”.

isotropic.description: If isotropic is true, it will be assumed that the material's physical properties are independent of the incident direction. This is for example true for most metals and glasses. If isotropic is set to false, then anisotropic materials (including orthotropic) will be considered. Then the input parameters should be provided as a function of the incident direction.

homogeneous.description: If it is set to false, non-homogeneous material needs to be considered in which physical properties varies inside the material. Physical properties should be provided accordingly if material is homogeneous or not.

magnetic.description: If this flag is true, it is assumed that the material has magnetic properties. If this flag is false, the material is assumed non-magnetic.

temperature.description: Base-temperature of material in Kelvin(K); T(°C) = T(K) - 273.15; Some assets have different temperature e.g. pedestrian, vehicle parts, ice, snow, rain.

lambert_emission.description: A Lambertian emitter has the same brightness (i.e. current per area per solid angle) when observed from all angles. Lambertian emission follows the Lambert's cosine law. Value 0 means that the property is not used, while 1 enables it

subsurface.description: If it is true, subsurface interactions will be considered on top of surface interactions.

subsurface_thickness.description: Thickness of volume (in micrometers [um]) to be considered as subsurface. The default value is the penetration depth which will be calculated by material model.

surface_displacement_uri.description: URI to an external file with displacement data. Surface displacement is the macro-surface pattern. Assets can have multiple displacements and they should be linked to their appropriate displacement group.

surface_roughness.description: Surface roughness is defined by the surface root-mean-square and the correlation length.

coating_materials.description: Coating refers to a layer of transparent or semi-transparent material on top of another material. An example is a layer of oil or water on top of asphalt.

layer_thickness.description: Thickness of the coating layer in micrometer.

ingredients.description: Ingredients are considered as impurities on top of the main material. For example, oxidization might be an ingredient of a metal. Ingredients order are considered inside the array.

distribution_pattern_uri.description: Link to external map of material distribution. Describes how material and the ingredients are distributed over the geometry.

physical_properties.description: Intrinsic physical material properties that do not change when material is applied to geometry.

refractive_index_uri.description: The refractive index is a complex function N (n + ik) that depends on the temperature and the wavelength. The data of the refractive index is provided as a table in the external glTF file given by the URI.

conductivity_uri.description: URI of an external file with tabular conductivity data [S/m].

mean_free_path.description: Mean free path in micrometer [um], for volumetric materials. It is the average distance travelled by light until it scatters at a scatterer. Value 0 means that the property is not used.

particle_density.description: It is the density of scatterers in the volume (in micrometer^3). Value 0 means that property is not used.

particle_cross_section.description: Effective cross section (in micrometer^2) of scatterers in the volume. Value 0 means that the property is not used.

emissive_coefficient_uri.description: URI to file with emissivity coefficient values. The ideal black body has the emissivity coefficient of 1.0.

effective_particle_area.description: Effective particle area of a material. Required by the Radar.

relative_permittivity.description: Ratio of the capacitance of a capacitor using that material as a dielectric

relative_permeability.description: It's the ratio of the permeability of a specific medium to the permeability of free space mu0

acoustic_impedance.description: Resistance an ultrasound beam encounters as it passes through a tissue

detection_wavelength_ranges.description: Array of wavelength ranges in which the material can be detected by sensors.

typical_sensor.description: Suitable for sensor from type X.
